footer.siteDescription: is the official platform for preventing cyberfraud in Luxembourg.
footer.patronage: under the patronage of the Ministry of the Economy

titles.title: Learn the right reflexes with a song!
Discover the video clip « Don’t click, check it, report it! » on YouTube...

video.linksTitle: Like the song on all music platforms.

items.name: Ministére de l'Agriculture, de l'Alimentation et de la Viticulture
Association des Compagnies D'Assurances de Réassurances

titles.title: Do you think you are a victim of fraud?
Ask yourself the 3 following questions to assess the situation:

cards.title: Are you unable to call the person back?
cards.body: Even on the phone number you had for them prior to their call, such as your bank’s branch office?

cards.title: Did the caller ask you to act quickly?
cards.body: And without complying with the usual security measures?

cards.title: Did the caller ask you for a secret code?
cards.body: Such as your card number, credentials or did they ask you to install an application?

cards.title: Did you answer “yes” to any of these questions?
cards.body:
Be careful!
It might be suspicious.

titles.title: Contact the right person for each situation!

accordionItems.title: Is it an issue related to your bank?
accordionItems.body:
Contact your bank’s call centre, your financial advisor or branch’s number during their opening times. If you do not have your branch or advisor's number, a contact number should be on any official document sent by the bank. 

If you do not have access to your branch’s number nor that of your advisor, a contact number must feature on all the official documents sent by your bank. If you cannot find it, use the online yellow pages to get your bank’s official telephone number.

__Out of hours: The phone number +352 491010 to block the LuxTrust certificate linked to your bank account and thus block access to your account.__

accordionItems.title: Is it a fraud related to your LuxTrust account?
accordionItems.body:
To suspend or revoke their certificate, customers can call LuxTrust’s Customer Care or go to the LuxTrust website - [www.luxtrust.com](https://www.luxtrust.com), in the _My LuxTrust area_, and click on _Temporarily suspend my certificate or Permanently revoke my certificate._

These procedures can also be carried out in person on LuxTrust's premises in Capellen (IVY Building, 13-15 Parc d'activités, L-8308 Capellen, Luxembourg) from Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm.

__Ensure you have the answers with you to the security questions you selected during the LuxTrust ID activation process. The operator will need them to identify you.__

accordionItems.title: Is the problem linked to the State’s guichet.lu portal and public services website?
accordionItems.body:
You may contact:
 - Phone: the helpdesk during opening hours: (+352) 247 82 000
 - Website: [guichet.public.lu](https://guichet.public.lu/fr/citoyens/actualites/2025/fevrier/12-govcert.html)
 - GOVCERT.LU reporting form: [https://govcert.lu/fr/signaler/](https://govcert.lu/fr/signaler/)

accordionItems.title: Need to know more on the different types of fraud?
accordionItems.body:
Contact the Grand-Ducal Police for other types of fraud via your local Police Station:
 - Map of police stations with phone numbers: [https://police.public.lu/fr/votre-police/postes-police.html](https://police.public.lu/fr/votre-police/postes-police.html)

accordionItems.title: Do you want to check whether a financial firm exists?
accordionItems.body:
You can contact the CSSF
 - Phone: +352 2625 1 2194
 - Website: [https://www.cssf.lu](https://www.cssf.lu)
 - Email: [direction@cssf.lu](mailto:direction@cssf.lu)

accordionItems.title: A question about cybersecurity?
accordionItems.body: The BEE SECURE Helpline is a confidential service for advice, for questions and practical advice about internet security and assistance with digital media. Call this service on +352 8002 1234 or [write to them](https://www.bee-secure.lu/fr/formulaire-contact-bee-secure-helpline/)

titles.title: Bear these key points in mind:

cards.title: BE CAREFUL WITH “TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE” ADS
cards.body: If it is too good to be true, it is probably suspicious, even on Christmas Day!

cards.title: DO NOT SHARE YOUR CREDENTIALS. NEVER.
cards.body: Respectable organisations will never request your ID details (user name, user number or password, PIN code) by email, text message, phone or via any messaging or social media application.

cards.title: REPORT SUSPICIOUS MESSAGES
cards.body: If you receive a suspicious message from your bank or an official institution, you can report it by calling your bank, your branch or your advisor, or the contact number of the institution which supposedly sent you a message. You may also use SPAMBEE (spambee.lu) to report emails and thus help protect other Luxembourgish residents.

cards.title: TAKE TIME BEFORE YOU CLICK
cards.body: Scammers generally want to create a sense of urgency and get you to act hastily. Take a break to come to your senses. You can always call back the bank or organisation that seems to be contacting you, to check whether they really phoned you in the first place. If in doubt, check it out!

cards.title: USE LUXTRUST WHENEVER POSSIBLE
cards.body: Use strong authentication mechanisms such as the LuxTrust Mobile app when available.

titles.title: 4 websites to know more about cyberfraud

cards.title: RELIABLE AND REALISTIC ADVICE
cards.body: BEE SECURE provides reliable and realistic advice about how to protect yourself online. The website provides a wide range of content about digital risks, current trends and good practices, as well as useful publications about how to navigate and understand the digital world.

cards.title: TOOLS TO PROTECT YOURSELF
cards.body: The Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity provides a variety of services and tools to help you actively protect yourself, either by reporting malicious content, or by helping you find security solutions providers.

cards.title: REPORT A CYBERFRAUD
body: The Spambee tool, provided by "National Cybersecurity Competence Center" (NC3), allows you to report and get rid of harmful content, while providing protection from content that has already been reported by other users.
If you cannot use Spambee but nevertheless wish to report a phishing website, CIRCL’s URL-Abuse service may also be accessed on your browser.

cards.title: THE NATIONAL CYBERSECURITY PORTAL
cards.body: Cybersecurity.lu is a portal to an ecosystem where you can find service providers with suitable security solutions for your needs.

titles.title: Phishing, online fraud… all you need to know!

cards.title: What is online fraud?
cards.body: The term ‘online fraud’ refers to a range of dishonest actions committed online, using unfair means to trick and obtain consent or material benefit or improper morals, that violate laws and regulations. Scamming is the most common form of fraud.

cards.title: What is phishing?
body: Phishing involves sending a message, generally an email, impersonating a trusted third-party (bank, administrations, social network, shipping firm, online trader etc.) to trick the victim into providing their identity or bank details, passwords or bank card numbers.
Emails used to be the most widespread means of communication, but scammers have since developped techniques using other media:

cards.title: What types of fraud do the Grand-Ducal Police see the most?
cards.body: There are many types of fraud. The Grand-Ducal Police have identified them and described their modus operandi on the following page:

privacy-policy.title: Privacy policy
privacy-policy.content:
# Privacy policy – Cyberfraud
This Privacy Policy outlines how personal data is collected and processed through the website [https://www.cyberfraud.lu](https://www.cyberfraud.lu) (hereinafter “the Website”), which is operated by the Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity (LHC).

We collect and process personal data in accordance with the applicable data protection legislations such as, but not limited to, Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regards to the processing of their personal data and the free movement of such data (“GDPR”) and the national law adopting GDPR.

It may occur that we change or amend our Privacy Policy in order to ensure that its content accurately reflects regulatory developments. Any such modification, if substantial, will be clearly communicated to you, either via the website or via other appropriate means. The latest applicable version will be available on our website.

Should you have any questions or remarks regarding this Privacy Policy, do not hesitate to contact us at [privacy@lhc.lu](mailto:privacy@lhc.lu).

---

## Processing of personal data

By “personal data” we understand any information that can identify you, both directly and indirectly.

By “processing” we refer to anything we do with such personal data, including collection, recording, organization, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction.

By “data controller” we understand the person responsible for the processing of your personal data, this is the entity which determines the means and purpose of the processing activities. For the Website and all related services, the data controller is: Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity g.i.e., 122, Rue Adolphe Fischer, L-1521 Luxembourg Grand-Duchy of Luxembourg Tel: (+352) 274 00 98 601

Email: [privacy@lhc.lu](mailto:privacy@lhc.lu) .

---

## What personal data do we collect on the Website and to which end?

When you are surfing the Website, we collect and process web server logs, including IP addresses, user-agents, URLs, date and time logs. We collect those logs for our legitimate interest as these logs enable the technical and functional management of our website. Furthermore, we analyse the data to ensure the optimal security of the Website.

When you contact us by mail, we process your contact information and any other details you provide us. We will use these details, if provided, for further case management and to facilitate our ticket system. In that case, we collect personal data for the public interest, to help our constituency handle security incidents (e.g. help with compromised websites).

Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity offers different services, where each service has its dedicated website and conditions of use.

We confirm that we process your personal data in a fair and lawful manner and only for the explicit and legitimate purposes as above-mentioned. At all times, we strive to ensure that your personal data is adequate, relevant and not excessive in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.

In case you enter and use one of the websites that are link to this website, personal data will be processed according to the privacy policies of these respective networks.

---

## Does the Website use cookies?

Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity uses analytics tools to collect usage information to improve the functioning of the website. In particular, such tools may collect the following usage information: partial IP address, operating system, browser and plugins, the type of device used to visit the website, behaviour on the Website (visited webpages, searches) and the origin of entry.

All stored usage information remains in Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity infrastructure, where the analytics tool is installed, and potentially on its related backup system.  

## First and third-party cookies

A cookie is a small text file that a website saves on your computer or mobile device when you visit the site. First party cookies are cookies set by the website you are visiting. Only that website can read them. In addition, a website might potentially use external services, which also set their own cookies, known as third-party cookies.

On the Website, LHC mostly uses _first party cookies_, which fall into two main categories:

**1.** **Essential cookies**: which are necessary for the technical functioning of the Website.

**2.**    **Analytics cookies**: which support LHC in generating anonymous Website statistics. This is performed with the use of Matomo ([https://matomo.org](https://matomo.org)), an open-source web analytics service. Matomo uses cookies to help analyse the use of the Website and to compile reports about website activity.

Below is a list of _third-party_ providers that may place cookies on your device when you visit the Website:

 - **YouTube** – to display embedded videos on the Website. If you do not give consent, the video will open in a new YouTube tab instead of playing directly on the page. [https://policies.google.com/privacy](https://policies.google.com/privacy)

- **Meta Pixel** – to track user interactions and measure the effectiveness of advertising campaigns on Facebook and Instagram. [https://www.facebook.com/privacy/policy](https://www.facebook.com/privacy/policy)

- **Snapchat Pixel** – similar to Meta Pixel, this cookie helps monitor the performance of ads and understand user behavior on the Website. [https://values.snap.com/privacy/privacy-policy](https://values.snap.com/privacy/privacy-policy)

_Every time you visit the Website, you will be prompted (via a banner) to accept all or accept only essential cookies. If you accept all cookies, it is considered that you provide your consent for analytics cookies. If you accept only essential cookies, a cookie will still be placed to prohibit any tracking for analytics purposes on our side._

---

## How long do we retain your personal data?

In no circumstances, we keep your personal data for a longer period than strictly necessary to fulfil the purpose for which it was collected.

As the retention period is dependent on the purpose for which the personal data were initially collected, the purpose is the criterion that is used to determine the appropriate retention period.

After the expiry of the retention period, we strive to securely erase, destroy or anonymize personal data that is no longer required in relation to the purpose for which they were collected.

However, if requested by local and national law, certain personal data may be retained for a longer period. For instance, for accounting purposes, such as but limited to, payment of the services fees and no-show fee for free events, data will be retained for the time required by the national law and for no longer than ten years.

---

## Sharing personal data

We formally confirm that we will not sell, rent or otherwise commercially transfer to or share with a third party any personal data.

The data submitted will only be made available to Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity personnel for the above-mentioned purposes.

As our web server is hosted and managed in Luxembourg, your personal data is in no circumstances transferred to third countries outside the EU.

---

## Security of your personal data

We are striving to keep your personal data secure. To that end, we have adopted the appropriate legal, organizational and technical precautions to prevent any unauthorised access and use of your personal data. These measures include, but are not limited to the encryption of all traffic between the Website and your browser.

---

## Your rights as a data subject

At Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity, we aim to be transparent, not only about how we process personal data about you, but also about your rights that are linked to such processing.

In particular, you have the right to access your personal data, to obtain the updating, the adjustment and the erasure of the personal data and you can exercise the rights to restrict and to object the processing. You can exercise the rights provided by articles 15 and the following of the GDPR contacting the following email address [privacy@lhc.lu](mailto:privacy@lhc.lu). In order to avoid unlawful access to your personal data, we will request you to provide a proof of your identity. If you have any queries about this Privacy Notice or experiencing any other privacy issue, we are striving to promptly dealing with any privacy-related complaints. If you have a complaint related to the processing of your personal data by Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity, please contact us.

terms-and-conditions.title: Terms and conditions
terms-and-conditions.content:
# Terms and Conditions – Cyberfraud

These terms govern the use of the website [https://www.cyberfraud.lu](https://www.cyberfraud.lu) (hereinafter “the Website).

By using the Website and its associated services, you agree to comply with these terms, established by Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity (LHC). 

By agreeing to these terms, you acknowledge and commit to adhering to the rules and responsibilities outlined below regarding the lawful and respectful use of the platform.

LHC may offer additional services governed by different terms. These terms apply solely to the use of the Website.

---

## Important Terms

**These terms include a number of important provisions that affect your rights and responsibilities, such as the disclaimers in** [**Disclaimers**](#disclaimers)**, your agreement to cover LHC for damages caused by your misuse of the Website in** [**Your Responsibility**](#your-responsibility)**, and an agreement to arbitrate disputes in** [**Disputes**](#disputes)**.**

---

## Your Permission to Use the Website

Subject to compliance with these terms, LHC grants you permission to use the Website. This permission is non-transferable, and each individual must agree to these terms independently to use the platform.

---

## Conditions for Use of the Website

Your permission to use this Website is subject to the following conditions:

- You may no longer use the Website if LHC contacts you directly to say that you may not.
- You must use the Website in accordance with Acceptable Use as defined here below.

---

## Acceptable Use

1. You may not break the law using the Website.
2. You may not engage in activities that compromise the security, functionality, or performance of the Website, such as hacking, data theft, or overloading the system with automated requests.
3. Automated tools, such as web crawlers, browser plug-ins, or add-ons, are prohibited unless used for indexing by a publicly available search engine.
4. You may not use the Website to send e-mail to distribution lists, newsgroups, or group mail aliases.
5. You may not falsely imply that you're affiliated with or endorsed by LHC.
6. You may not hyperlink to images or other non-hypertext content on the Website.
7. You may not remove any marks showing proprietary ownership from materials you download from the website.
8. You may not disable, avoid, or circumvent any security or access restrictions of the Website.
9. You may not strain infrastructure of the Website with an unreasonable volume of requests, or requests designed to impose an unreasonable load on information systems underlying the website.
10. You may not encourage or help anyone in violation of these terms.
11. Impersonation of others through the Website is strictly forbidden.

---

## Cookies and embedded content

Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity uses analytics tools to collect usage information to improve the functioning of the website. In particular, such tools may collect the following usage information: partial IP address, operating system, browser and plugins, the type of device used to visit the website, behaviour on the Website (visited webpages, searches) and the origin of entry.

All stored usage information remains in Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity infrastructure, where the analytics tool is installed, and potentially on its related backup system. 

The Privacy Policy provides an overview of the first and third-party cookies for this Website.

---

## Your data

We respect your Personal Information and aim to comply with applicable Data Protection legislation from time to time in place. We particularly comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and all applicable data protection laws to safeguard your Personal Information.

For information please directly refer to our [Privacy Policy](/privacy-policy)

---

## Enforcement

LHC may investigate and prosecute violations of these terms to the fullest legal extent. LHC may notify and cooperate with law enforcement authorities in prosecuting violations of the law and these terms. LHC reserves the right to change, redact, and delete content on the Website for any reason.

---

## Disclaimers

The Website may hyperlink to and integrate websites and services run by others. LHC does not make any warranty about services run by others, or content they may provide. Use of services run by others may be governed by other terms between you and the one running service.

---

#### Your Responsibility

You agree to indemnify LHC from legal claims by others related to your breach of these terms, or breach of these terms by others using your data on the Website. Both you and LHC agree to notify the other side of any legal claims for which you might have to indemnify LHC as soon as possible. You agree to allow LHC to control investigation, defense, and settlement of legal claims for which you would have to indemnify LHC, and to cooperate with those efforts. LHC agrees to not accept any settlement that admits fault for you or imposes obligations on you without your prior agreement.

---

## Feedback

LHC welcomes your feedback and suggestions for the Website. See the Contact section below for ways to get in touch with us.

You agree that LHC will be free to act on feedback and suggestions you provide, and that LHC won't have to notify you that your feedback was used, get your permission to use it, or pay you. You agree not to submit feedback or suggestions that you believe might be confidential or proprietary, to you or others.

---

## Disputes

Luxembourg law will govern any dispute, including any legal proceedings, related to these terms or your use of the Website.

---

## General Terms

These terms embody all the terms of agreement between you and LHC about use of the Website. These terms entirely replace any other agreements about your use of the Website, written or not.

---

## Contact

You may notify LHC under these terms, and send questions to LHC, at [info@lhc.lu](mailto:info@lhc.lu) .

Luxembourg House of Cybersecurity, 122, Rue Adolphe Fischer L-1521 Luxembourg, Grand-Duchy of Luxembourg.
